citation.article-title: Wolinella gen. nov., Wolinella succinogenes (Vibrio succinogenes Wolin et al.) comb. nov., and description of Bacteroides gracilis sp. nov., Wolinella recta sp. nov., Campylobacter concisus sp. nov., and Eikenella corrodens from humans with periodontal disease.

p.s: Wolinella (Wol in el'la. M.L. dim. ending -ella; M. L. fem. n. Wolinella named for M. J. Wolin, American bacteriologist who first isolated and named the organism designated here as the type species of the genus)
Helical, curved, or straight, unbranched cells, 0.5 to 1 by 2 to 6 Î¼m, having rounded or tapered ends.
Rapid, darting motility is by means of a single, polar flagellum.
Anaerobic; some strains can grow in the presence of 5% oxygen but not in air enriched with 10% COZ.
Carbohydrates are not fermented and do not support growth.
Growth is stimulated in broth cultures by formate and fumarate.
Hydrogen and formate are used as energy sources (35).
Formate is oxidized to produce hydrogen and carbon dioxide.
Nitrate is reduced, and hydrogen sulfide is produced.
The G+C content of the DNA is 42 to 49 mol% (thermal denaturation method).
The type species is Wolinella succinogenes (Wolin et al.) comb. nov.
